case.name: WorldAudio Limited v Australian Communications and Media Authority [2006] FCA 8 (16 January 2006)

citphrases.citphrase: administrative law
minister declining to exercise a power on own motion

whether decision to make determination on decision-maker's own motion is "a decision to which this act applies" within the meaning of the administrative decisions (judicial review) act 1977 (cth) ["the ad(jr) act"]
whether "a decision under an enactment" being the aboriginal and torres strait islander heritage protection act 1984 (cth) ("the act ")
whether a decision of an administrative character
whether a conclusion reached on the way to a substantive and operative decision
whether minister under a duty to make a decision to which the ad(jr) act applies

whether state minister as delegate of commonwealth minister an "officer of the commonwealth"
whether making a decision as to whether or not to make a determination under s 21d(2) or s 21e(2) of the act constitutes "conduct" within s 6(1) of the ad(jr) act practice and procedure

whether injunction available to restrain removal by third party of object potentially the subject of a declaration of preservation by minister

whether secretary's refusal to accede to request to stop trials was a "decision" within the meaning of s 5 adjr act
whether incorporated "right to life" association is a "person aggrieved" with standing to challenge the secretary's "decision".

citances.sentence: There is a reasonably long line of authority under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 (Cth) to the effect that a refusal to do something that an applicant is entitled to ask for nonetheless constitutes a decision: see, for example, WorldAudio Ltd v Australia Communications and Media Authority [2006] FCA 8 ; (2006) 228 ALR 733 at [30] , and the authorities referred to there.
At the same time, the decision also became the subject of proceedings in the Federal Court of Australia ( WorldAudio Ltd v Australian Communications and Media Authority [2006] FCA 8).
